title: Ezra Chapter 4 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezra chapter 4 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezra Chapter 4 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezra Chapter 4.

questions.question: Who came to Zerubbabel and the chief of the fathers offering to help build the temple?
options: The adversaries of Judah and Benjamin
questions.correctAnswer: The adversaries of Judah and Benjamin
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:1 states that the adversaries of Judah and Benjamin heard about the building of the temple and came to offer help.

questions.question: What reason did the adversaries give for wanting to build with the children of the captivity?
options: They sought the same God and sacrificed to Him since the days of Esarhaddon
They wanted to control the temple
They were ordered by the king
They wanted to rebuild their own city
questions.correctAnswer: They sought the same God and sacrificed to Him since the days of Esarhaddon
questions.explanation: According to Ezra 4:2, the adversaries said they seek the same God and have sacrificed to Him since the days of Esarhaddon king of Assur.

questions.question: How did Zerubbabel and Jeshua respond to the offer of help from the adversaries?
options: They rejected it, saying the adversaries had nothing to do with building the house of God
They asked for a written agreement
questions.correctAnswer: They rejected it, saying the adversaries had nothing to do with building the house of God
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:3 records that Zerubbabel, Jeshua, and the leaders said they would build the temple themselves as commanded by King Cyrus, rejecting the adversaries' offer.

questions.question: What did the people of the land do to the people of Judah while they were building the temple?
options: Weakened their hands and troubled them
questions.correctAnswer: Weakened their hands and troubled them
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:4 says the people of the land weakened the hands of the people of Judah and troubled them in building.

questions.question: During whose reign did the adversaries write an accusation against the inhabitants of Judah and Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: Ahasuerus
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:6 states that in the beginning of the reign of Ahasuerus, the adversaries wrote an accusation against Judah and Jerusalem.

questions.question: In what language was the letter written to King Artaxerxes?
questions.correctAnswer: Syrian
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:7 mentions the letter was written and interpreted in the Syrian tongue.

questions.question: Who were the writers of the letter against Jerusalem sent to King Artaxerxes?
options: Rehum the chancellor and Shimshai the scribe
questions.correctAnswer: Rehum the chancellor and Shimshai the scribe
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:8 identifies Rehum the chancellor and Shimshai the scribe as the writers of the letter against Jerusalem.

questions.question: Which groups were included among the companions who sent the letter to King Artaxerxes?
questions.correctAnswer: The Dinaites, Apharsathchites, Tarpelites, Babylonians
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:9 lists these groups among those who wrote the letter to King Artaxerxes.

questions.question: What was the main accusation in the letter sent to King Artaxerxes about Jerusalem?
options: That Jerusalem was rebellious and bad, building the city and walls would harm the king's revenue
That Jerusalem was peaceful and loyal to the king
That Jerusalem was a new city with no history
That Jerusalem was protected by the king
questions.correctAnswer: That Jerusalem was rebellious and bad, building the city and walls would harm the king's revenue
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:12-13 states the letter accused the Jews of building a rebellious city that would cause loss of toll, tribute, and custom to the king.

questions.question: Why did the adversaries send the letter to the king, according to their own words?
options: Because they had maintenance from the king's palace and it was not fitting to see the king's dishonor
Because they wanted to support the rebuilding
Because they were commanded by the priests
questions.correctAnswer: Because they had maintenance from the king's palace and it was not fitting to see the king's dishonor
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:14 explains their letter was sent because they received maintenance from the king's palace and did not want to see the king dishonored.

questions.question: What did King Artaxerxes command after reading the letter about Jerusalem?
options: To cause the men to cease building the city until further orders
To allow the building to continue
To send more workers to help
questions.correctAnswer: To cause the men to cease building the city until further orders
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:21 records the king's command that the building should cease until another commandment was given.

questions.question: True or False: The work on the house of God in Jerusalem continued without interruption during the reign of Darius.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:24 states the work ceased until the second year of the reign of Darius king of Persia.

questions.question: True or False: The letter to King Artaxerxes was written in the Hebrew tongue.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:7 says the letter was written and interpreted in the Syrian tongue, not Hebrew.

questions.question: True or False: The adversaries accused Jerusalem of causing harm to kings and provinces by moving sedition within the city of old time.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:15 states that the city was rebellious and hurtful unto kings and provinces because it had moved sedition in old times.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Ezra 4:3: 'Ye have nothing to do with us to build an house unto our God; but we ourselves together will build unto the LORD God of Israel, as ______.'
options: king Cyrus the king of Persia hath commanded us
questions.correctAnswer: king Cyrus the king of Persia hath commanded us
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:3 clearly states that Zerubbabel and the leaders said they would build as king Cyrus the king of Persia had commanded.

medium.title: Ezra Chapter 4 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezra Chapter 4 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with opposition at work while trying to do what is right. Based on Ezra 4, what biblical truth would you share about persevering through trials?
options: Trust God's command and keep working faithfully despite opposition
Give up when people oppose your efforts
Ignore God's instructions and follow only human advice
Seek to please others rather than God
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God's command and keep working faithfully despite opposition
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:3 shows Zerubbabel and others refused to be discouraged by opposition and continued building the temple as commanded by King Cyrus, demonstrating faith and perseverance through trials (Ezra 4:4-5, 4:23-24).

questions.question: How does Ezra 4 teach us about humility and contentment in the face of opposition from others?
options: Remain humble, obey God's commands, and content yourself with doing His will
Respond aggressively to those who oppose you
Boast about your achievements to discourage opponents
Avoid doing any work that might cause conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Remain humble, obey God's commands, and content yourself with doing His will
questions.explanation: The leaders in Ezra 4:3 humbly declined the offer to build with the adversaries because they were focused on obedience to God’s command through King Cyrus, showing humility and contentment in God's plan despite opposition (Ezra 4:1-3, 4:21-22).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to compromise integrity at work to gain favor. Based on Ezra 4, what biblical principle would you encourage them to follow?
options: Maintain integrity and refuse to join those who oppose God’s work
Compromise to avoid conflict and gain approval
Ignore God's commands if others disagree
Seek personal gain above all else
questions.correctAnswer: Maintain integrity and refuse to join those who oppose God’s work
questions.explanation: Zerubbabel and Jeshua refused to join the adversaries who claimed to worship God but had incompatible motives (Ezra 4:2-3). This teaches the importance of integrity and obedience to God’s commands rather than compromising for approval (Ezra 4:4-5).

questions.question: How does Ezra 4 demonstrate the importance of prayer and spiritual discipline in the face of opposition?
options: Continually seek God’s guidance and rely on Him amid challenges
Ignore prayer and focus only on human advice
Resort to anger and retaliation against opponents
Stop working for God when discouraged
questions.correctAnswer: Continually seek God’s guidance and rely on Him amid challenges
questions.explanation: Though not explicitly mentioning prayer, the faithfulness of the leaders to continue building according to God’s command (Ezra 4:3) implies reliance on God’s guidance and spiritual discipline amid opposition (Ezra 4:4-5, 4:23-24).

questions.question: When faced with false accusations, how does Ezra 4 teach us to respond in a godly manner?
options: Trust God’s justice and remain obedient rather than retaliate
Ignore the accusations and continue without concern
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God’s justice and remain obedient rather than retaliate
questions.explanation: The Jews faced accusations from their adversaries (Ezra 4:6-16), yet they continued obeying God’s commands. King Artaxerxes’ investigation and letter (Ezra 4:17-22) shows that justice comes through God’s providence, teaching trust and obedience under false accusations.

questions.question: How does Ezra 4 teach us about the importance of obedience to God’s Word in family and community life?
options: Obey God’s commands together as a community for spiritual success
Allow others to influence you to disobey God
Build your own plans without consulting God
questions.correctAnswer: Obey God’s commands together as a community for spiritual success
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:3 shows Zerubbabel, Jeshua, and the leaders rejecting help from adversaries to obey God’s command to build the temple, emphasizing community obedience to God’s Word for spiritual unity and success (Ezra 4:1-3, 4:24).

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because their good work is hindered by others. Based on Ezra 4, what biblical truth would encourage them?
options: God’s work may be delayed but will not be stopped if you remain faithful
Give up because opposition means failure
Ignore God’s commands to avoid conflict
Seek revenge on those who hinder you
questions.correctAnswer: God’s work may be delayed but will not be stopped if you remain faithful
questions.explanation: Though the work on the temple ceased temporarily due to opposition (Ezra 4:23-24), the leaders remained faithful and resumed later, teaching perseverance and trust in God’s timing (Ezra 4:4-5, 4:23-24).

questions.question: True or False: The adversaries claimed to worship the same God as the Jews and wanted to help build the temple.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:2 states the adversaries said they sought the same God and sacrificed to Him, claiming they wanted to assist in building the temple, though their motives were questioned (Ezra 4:1-3).

questions.question: True or False: King Artaxerxes ordered the building of Jerusalem to continue without interruption.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: According to Ezra 4:21, King Artaxerxes commanded that the building of Jerusalem cease until further orders, showing a temporary halt to the work (Ezra 4:17-22).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Zerubbabel and Jeshua told the adversaries, 'Ye have ______ to do with us to build an house unto our God.'
questions.correctAnswer: nothing
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:3 clearly states that Zerubbabel and Jeshua told the adversaries they had nothing to do with them in building the house of God, emphasizing separation to obey God’s command.

questions.question: How does the opposition described in Ezra 4 teach us about maintaining integrity at work?
options: Stay true to God’s commands even if others try to weaken your efforts
Ignore God’s word to please coworkers
questions.correctAnswer: Stay true to God’s commands even if others try to weaken your efforts
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:4-5 shows the people of the land tried to weaken and trouble the Jews in building, yet the leaders remained committed to God’s command, teaching the importance of integrity despite opposition.

questions.question: What does Ezra 4 teach about the role of government authority in God’s work?
options: Government authority can both hinder and allow God’s work based on their judgments
Government has no role in spiritual matters
questions.correctAnswer: Government authority can both hinder and allow God’s work based on their judgments
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:21-22 shows King Artaxerxes ordered the building to stop, while earlier kings allowed it (Ezra 4:5), indicating government authority can affect the progress of God’s work.

questions.question: Based on Ezra 4, how should we respond when others falsely accuse us of rebellion or wrongdoing in our service to God?
options: Trust God to vindicate you and continue obedient service
Stop serving God to avoid accusations
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to vindicate you and continue obedient service
questions.explanation: The Jews faced accusations of rebellion (Ezra 4:12-16), yet they remained faithful. King Artaxerxes’ investigation vindicated the accusations as historical but temporarily halted work, teaching trust in God and perseverance (Ezra 4:18-22).

questions.question: How does Ezra 4 encourage believers to be faithful in church life and fellowship despite external opposition?
options: Stay united, obey God’s commands, and continue God’s work together
Separate and isolate yourself from others
questions.correctAnswer: Stay united, obey God’s commands, and continue God’s work together
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:3 shows the leaders working together to build the temple despite adversaries’ attempts to join or stop them, teaching unity and faithfulness in church life amid opposition (Ezra 4:1-3, 4:23-24).

questions.question: What practical lesson about stewardship and work ethic is taught by the builders’ response to opposition in Ezra 4?
options: Be diligent and faithful in your work even when others oppose or try to discourage you
Stop working if others criticize you
Work only when praised by others
Ignore God’s commands to avoid hardship
questions.correctAnswer: Be diligent and faithful in your work even when others oppose or try to discourage you
questions.explanation: Despite opposition and attempts to frustrate their purpose (Ezra 4:4-5), the builders remained faithful to their task as commanded by God through King Cyrus (Ezra 4:3), demonstrating strong work ethic and stewardship.

hard.title: Ezra Chapter 4 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezra Chapter 4.

questions.question: Who approached Zerubbabel and the chief fathers offering to help build the temple, claiming they worshipped the same God?
options: The adversaries of Judah and Benjamin
questions.correctAnswer: The adversaries of Judah and Benjamin
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:2 states that the adversaries of Judah and Benjamin came to Zerubbabel and the chief fathers asking to build with them because they also worshipped the same God.

questions.question: What reason did Zerubbabel and the chief fathers give for refusing the offer of help to build the temple?
options: They had a command from King Cyrus to build alone
They did not trust the adversaries' God
questions.correctAnswer: They had a command from King Cyrus to build alone
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:3 explains that Zerubbabel and Jeshua said the adversaries had nothing to do with building the house of God, as they would build it themselves according to King Cyrus' command.

questions.question: What tactics did the people of the land use to hinder the Jews from building the temple?
options: Weakened their hands and troubled them in building
questions.correctAnswer: Weakened their hands and troubled them in building
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:4 records that the people of the land weakened the hands of the people of Judah and troubled them in building the temple.

questions.question: During whose reigns did the adversaries hire counselors to frustrate the Jews’ building efforts?
questions.correctAnswer: From Cyrus until Darius
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:5 states that counselors were hired to frustrate their purpose all the days of Cyrus king of Persia until the reign of Darius king of Persia.

questions.question: In what language was the letter sent to King Artaxerxes by the adversaries written and interpreted?
questions.correctAnswer: Syrian language
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:7 explains that the letter sent to Artaxerxes was written and interpreted in the Syrian tongue.

questions.question: Which of the following groups was NOT mentioned as part of those who wrote the letter against Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: The Egyptians
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:9 lists many groups including the Elamites, Babylonians, and Apharsites, but the Egyptians are not mentioned.

questions.question: What was the main accusation made against the Jews rebuilding Jerusalem in the letter to Artaxerxes?
options: They were building a rebellious and bad city
They were conspiring against the king
They were refusing to pay taxes
questions.correctAnswer: They were building a rebellious and bad city
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:12 states the accusation that the Jews were building the rebellious and bad city, setting up walls and joining the foundations.

questions.question: According to the letter, what would happen if Jerusalem was rebuilt and the walls set up again?
options: The king would lose revenue from toll, tribute, and custom
The city would become a major trade center
The Jews would become independent from Persia
questions.correctAnswer: The king would lose revenue from toll, tribute, and custom
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:13 states that if the city and walls were rebuilt, they would not pay toll, tribute, and custom, thus damaging the king's revenue.

questions.question: What justification did the adversaries give for sending the accusation to the king?
options: They had maintenance from the king's palace and sought to avoid dishonoring the king
They wanted to gain favor with Artaxerxes
They sought to punish the Jews for rebellion
They wanted to claim the land for themselves
questions.correctAnswer: They had maintenance from the king's palace and sought to avoid dishonoring the king
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:14 explains that because they had maintenance from the king's palace and it was not proper to see the king dishonored, they sent the accusation.

questions.question: True or False: King Artaxerxes ordered that the rebuilding of Jerusalem should continue without interruption.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:21 shows that the king commanded that the building should cease until another command was given.

questions.question: What was found when a search was made in the records regarding Jerusalem’s history?
options: The city had made insurrection against kings and caused rebellion and sedition
The city was always loyal to the king
The city was never built before
The city was a peaceful trade hub
questions.correctAnswer: The city had made insurrection against kings and caused rebellion and sedition
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:19 states that the search found that Jerusalem had made insurrection against kings and that rebellion and sedition had been made there.

questions.question: Which kings are referred to in the letter as having ruled over Jerusalem and received toll, tribute, and custom?
options: Mighty kings over Jerusalem beyond the river
questions.correctAnswer: Mighty kings over Jerusalem beyond the river
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:20 mentions mighty kings over Jerusalem who ruled beyond the river and to whom toll, tribute, and custom were paid.

questions.question: What was the immediate effect after the copy of King Artaxerxes' letter was read before Rehum and Shimshai?
options: They went quickly to Jerusalem and forced the Jews to stop working
They destroyed the foundation of the temple
They appealed to the king again
questions.correctAnswer: They went quickly to Jerusalem and forced the Jews to stop working
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:23 states that after reading the king's letter, Rehum, Shimshai, and their companions hastened to Jerusalem and made the Jews cease work by force and power.

questions.question: How long did the work on the house of God in Jerusalem cease after the opposition?
options: Until the second year of Darius king of Persia
Until the reign of Artaxerxes ended
questions.correctAnswer: Until the second year of Darius king of Persia
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:24 records that the work ceased until the second year of the reign of Darius king of Persia.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The adversaries accused Jerusalem of being a ______ and hurtful city that had moved sedition in old times.
questions.correctAnswer: rebellious
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:15 indicates that the city was known from the records to be rebellious and hurtful, having moved sedition previously.

theological.title: Ezra Chapter 4 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezra Chapter 4 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the primary reason Zerubbabel and the leaders refused to allow the adversaries to help build the temple?
options: They had nothing to do with building the house of God
They did not trust the adversaries' skills
They wanted to build the temple in secret
They were commanded by the king to exclude them
questions.correctAnswer: They had nothing to do with building the house of God
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:3 states, 'Ye have nothing to do with us to build an house unto our God; but we ourselves together will build unto the LORD God of Israel.' This demonstrates the leaders’ theological concern about who participates in the sacred work, reflecting God's holiness and separation (cf. Nehemiah 13:30; 2 Corinthians 6:14–17; John 2:16; 1 Corinthians 3:17).

questions.question: What tactic did the people of the land use against the Jews during the temple construction?
options: They weakened their hands and troubled them in building
They bribed officials to stop the work
questions.correctAnswer: They weakened their hands and troubled them in building
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:4 says, 'Then the people of the land weakened the hands of the people of Judah, and troubled them in building.' This shows opposition through discouragement and disruption, illustrating the spiritual warfare and human opposition believers may face (cf. Exodus 17:11-12; Nehemiah 4:7-8; Ephesians 6:12; 2 Corinthians 10:3-5).

questions.question: During whose reign did the adversaries write an accusation against the inhabitants of Judah and Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: Ahasuerus
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:6 states, 'And in the reign of Ahasuerus, in the beginning of his reign, wrote they unto him an accusation against the inhabitants of Judah and Jerusalem.' This reflects the ongoing opposition over generations, showing the persistence of spiritual and political resistance to God's work (cf. Daniel 6:1-24; Nehemiah 2:19; Acts 4:1-22; 1 Thessalonians 2:14-15).

questions.question: Which language was the letter to Artaxerxes written and interpreted in?
questions.correctAnswer: Syrian
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:7 records that the letter was 'written in the Syrian tongue, and interpreted in the Syrian tongue.' This indicates the cultural and linguistic diversity in the Persian empire and the importance of communication in opposition to God's people (cf. Ezra 4:8-9; Daniel 2:4-6; Acts 2:6-11; Revelation 7:9).

questions.question: What accusation was made against Jerusalem in the letter sent to King Artaxerxes?
options: That it was a rebellious and hurtful city that had caused sedition before
That it was uninhabitable and desolate
That it was a city of peace and submission
That it was a new city with no history
questions.correctAnswer: That it was a rebellious and hurtful city that had caused sedition before
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:15 states the city 'is a rebellious city, and hurtful unto kings and provinces, and that they have moved sedition within the same of old time.' This highlights the persistent sinful rebellion against God’s authority and earthly rulers, consistent with the biblical theme of human rebellion (cf. Isaiah 1:4; Jeremiah 6:14; Romans 1:18-32; Revelation 17:6).

questions.question: What was the economic concern mentioned in the letter as a reason to stop rebuilding Jerusalem?
options: Loss of toll, tribute, and custom
questions.correctAnswer: Loss of toll, tribute, and custom
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:13 says, 'if this city be builded... then will they not pay toll, tribute, and custom.' This shows the political and economic implications tied to rebellion and disobedience, consistent with biblical themes of justice and stewardship (cf. Romans 13:6-7; Nehemiah 5:15; Proverbs 29:4; Matthew 22:21).

questions.question: Who were Rehum and Shimshai in the context of this chapter?
options: Rehum was the chancellor, and Shimshai was the scribe
Rehum was a priest, and Shimshai was a prophet
Rehum was a king, and Shimshai was a general
Rehum was a builder, and Shimshai was a worker
questions.correctAnswer: Rehum was the chancellor, and Shimshai was the scribe
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:8 identifies 'Rehum the chancellor and Shimshai the scribe' as authors of the letter against Jerusalem. Their roles reflect political opposition to God's redemptive work, paralleling spiritual opposition seen throughout Scripture (cf. Nehemiah 6:10-14; Matthew 27:2; Acts 4:1-3; Revelation 13:7).

questions.question: What was King Artaxerxes' response after reading the letter about Jerusalem?
options: To command that the building cease until further notice
To encourage the rebuilding to continue
To ignore the letter and do nothing
To order the destruction of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: To command that the building cease until further notice
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:21 records, 'Give ye now commandment to cause these men to cease, and that this city be not builded, until another commandment shall be given from me.' This shows how earthly authorities can be instruments in opposing God's plans, reflecting the tension between divine sovereignty and human government (cf. Daniel 3:16-18; Acts 5:29; Romans 13:1-7; Revelation 17:17).

questions.question: According to the letter to King Artaxerxes, why was it not proper for the adversaries to see the king’s dishonor?
options: Because they had maintenance from the king's palace
questions.correctAnswer: Because they had maintenance from the king's palace
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:14 states, 'Now because we have maintenance from the king's palace, and it was not meet for us to see the king's dishonour.' This suggests political loyalty used to justify opposition, reflecting the role of earthly allegiance in spiritual contexts (cf. Jeremiah 29:7; Romans 13:1-2; 1 Peter 2:13-17; Revelation 13:2).

questions.question: What historical proof did the adversaries appeal to in their letter to justify stopping Jerusalem's rebuilding?
options: The book of the records of thy fathers
questions.correctAnswer: The book of the records of thy fathers
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:15 says, 'That search may be made in the book of the records of thy fathers... for which cause was this city destroyed.' They appealed to historical precedent to legitimize opposition, highlighting the importance of history and covenant faithfulness (cf. Deuteronomy 32:7; Psalm 78:5-8; Romans 15:4; Hebrews 11:32-40).

questions.question: What was the outcome after Artaxerxes' letter was read to the adversaries in Jerusalem?
options: They made the Jews cease work by force and power
They ignored the letter and continued building
They negotiated peace with the Jews
questions.correctAnswer: They made the Jews cease work by force and power
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:23 states, 'they went up in haste to Jerusalem unto the Jews, and made them to cease by force and power.' This illustrates the opposition believers face in their obedience and the cost of faithfulness (cf. Nehemiah 4:17-18; Acts 5:40-41; 2 Timothy 3:12; Revelation 2:10).

questions.question: How long did the work on the house of God cease according to this chapter?
options: Until the second year of the reign of Darius king of Persia
questions.correctAnswer: Until the second year of the reign of Darius king of Persia
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:24 records, 'So it ceased unto the second year of the reign of Darius king of Persia.' This shows God's timing and sovereignty over the restoration process (cf. Ezra 5:1; Daniel 2:21; Habakkuk 2:3; Ecclesiastes 3:1).

questions.question: Which kings’ reigns are mentioned as the time span during which the adversaries sought to frustrate the Jews' building efforts?
questions.correctAnswer: From Cyrus to Darius
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:5 says opposition persisted 'all the days of Cyrus king of Persia, even until the reign of Darius king of Persia.' This highlights the long-standing spiritual opposition to God's redemptive work (cf. Nehemiah 2:19-20; Daniel 6:1-28; Psalm 127:1; John 15:18-20).

questions.question: What nations are listed among those who wrote against Jerusalem to King Artaxerxes?
questions.correctAnswer: Dinaites, Apharsathchites, Tarpelites, Babylonians
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:9 lists these nations among others opposing Jerusalem. This reflects the geopolitical opposition to God's people from diverse groups, consistent with biblical themes of spiritual hostility (cf. Genesis 10; Psalm 83; Revelation 17; Ephesians 6:12).

questions.question: What reason did the adversaries give to King Artaxerxes for wanting to stop the rebuilding of Jerusalem?
options: The city was rebellious and would cause loss of royal revenue
The city was too small to be important
They wanted to build a new city instead
questions.correctAnswer: The city was rebellious and would cause loss of royal revenue
questions.explanation: Ezra 4:13-16 explains the adversaries’ claim that rebuilding would cause loss of tolls and tribute and that the city was rebellious. This reflects the biblical reality of sin impacting society and governance (cf. Isaiah 1:4; Jeremiah 22:3; Romans 13:3-4; Revelation 18:2).
